Confident people speaking strongly outside their expertise is a great danger. 
My example is nuclear promoters without grid construction experience. 

Nuclear electricity must have a very big grid. Grids are Frighteningly expensive to build.

The Australian nuclear promoters want to fill the existing national electric grid but we need to remove all fossil fuel with 10 times more electricity. 

But 10 times more national grid capacity is Frighteningly ridiculous. 
So 10 times more nuclear electricity is impossible.

But medical doctors, and earth engineers and nuclear chemists and ....... confidential speak about fossil fueled CO2 emissions worldwide. 

The nuclear alternative will be so big that nuclear will  be in the way. 
Unworkable and unaffordable.

comment_text: When Vinh was teaching you the speaking with melody concept, a huge part he left out is making sure you are speaking in a major key versus a minor key. When a person habitually ends sentences on a minor 3rd, they are perceived as being a negative “downer”. Speak in a major key (think radio and tv hosts). You’ll lift up the room, rather than bring it down.

🙏🏻🙏🏻🙏🏻🙏🏻🙏🏻🙏🏻🙏🏻🙏🏻🙏🏻Thank you so very much. I have worked so hard to learn every position at work. I go above and beyond in every way. I have finally gotten promoted into management and I am failing miserably. When I speak the whole room goes silent. No one will even look in my direction. It is the most humiliating thing. I do more. comment_text: A long time ago I was doing a student job as a night receptionist in a student dorm. Part of the job was picking up the phone and patching parents through to their kids – yes, I'm THAT old 😂. One time a mother, just before I passed her on, told me I had a very suave voice. My current SO says a similar thing: I have the perfect voice for a late night Jazz program on NPR. I write stories for fun, and sometimes I record them, pacing around, waving my hands, changing my posture while reading them out loud. It's all about acting, really. I believe I knew quite a few things of what Vinh Giang has been talking about, but at the very least it made me more aware of them.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text: As a 40-year-old man who’s had his fair share of moments struggling to be heard, this conversation really hit home. Vinh is right — too many of us go through life treating our voice like just a tool instead of an instrument. I spent years in meetings feeling invisible, even though I had good ideas. Once I started paying attention to how I spoke — pacing, volume, even using pauses — people began to notice. I do agree though, not everyone will transform in 3–6 months like he says. For some of us, it takes longer to break old habits. But his point stands: communication is a skill, and if you invest in it, it can change your life.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
1:24:58 I lived in the US for just 2 years at my critical ages, from 10 to 12, I think had brought me to where I am. I do feel the opposite “discrimination “, the benefits I get from sounding like an American in Japan.

But I do recall trying hard to sound like the rest of the class. Thankfully, my school was good not to bully me, but one time when I called a friend from afar, she looked back, smiled, and as innocent as she was, said, “ I like the way you say my name. It sounds so cute!” I knew she didn’t mean anything other than what she said, and I didn’t feel anything at the instant, but it stuck with me, and I feel like that was the turning point for me to realize I had an accent, or maybe I came to realize the ideology of “accents” for the first time in my life. Children are so naive and brutal😅

I have met many people with similar backgrounds where they had lived in other countries growing up and I notice that not all of them are without accents. I thought those without accents just had better hearing… and there could be that and other circumstances affecting it for sure, but when I got into university and started taking foreign language classes, I had a different idea. Classmates who speak perfect sounding American English did not sound perfect in a Chinese class; in fact, they sounded like an American trying to speak Chinese. It felt so odd to me… but I concluded that some people just automatically pick up the second language accent (good hearing, learning from a younger age, unconscious observations) so they cannot apply that to a new language in a older age - but might have a chance if they have a chance to be put in a hyper immersive environment even as adults.
author: @bqpdobqpd

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
Voice range 
Voice pace - go slower if you want to highlight it, go faster if it's not that important.
Voice volume - go lower in the voice if its important 
Voice emotion  - move your face and express your emotions


VAKS

Pause - pause after saying something to amplify its emotion

--- 

• Record and review ( Record a video of yourself while standing, talking for 5 minutes)

1. Auditory review ( only listen to your voice  ) 

- Check out the five vocal foundations ( rate of speech, volume, pitch, tonality and pauses )

2. Visual Review ( Put your voice on mute )

3. Get the video Transcribed.

comment_text:
2:25:00 It's actually a psychological reason ( a defensive mechanism kinda ), not an objective desire to use these clutter words .
and it stems from the person's environment,
so if he pauses, people around him often interrupts him before he can finish 
so by humming, stammering his trying to indirectly inform them that he still has more to say, 
the solution proposed by this speaker (vinh) is effective, but only with respectable people around you that actually wait for you to finish. but not with people who often cut you because they think you finish talking when you pause . 
and tbh i hate this type of people who are exited so bad to cut you so they can say their part or opinion so quickly  
it shows narcissism and lack of respect and it shows they don't even care of what you saying

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text: Hi, I have a music degree and wanted to chime in here at 23:48. The emotions you feel with music is learned, and different cultures associate different emotions with different sounds. The emotions are mostly driven by the intervals between the notes, although rhythm certainly has an important role on how much energy is there. Good engaging music creates tension (dissonance) and then releases (resonance) it. A related book I'd recommend is called "This is Your Brain on Music."

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
Hola, DOAC.

Gracias por el excelente contenido, lo consumo con frecuencia, especialmente a través de YouTube Music. Sin embargo, encontré un problema: en esa plataforma solo está disponible la versión traducida al español, y personalmente prefiero la versión original, incluso siendo hablante nativo de español.

Valoro mucho el esfuerzo por ampliar la audiencia, pero creo que aún hay oportunidades de mejora en la calidad de la traducción, ya que a veces se pierde parte del mensaje y el contexto. Les animo a seguir trabajando en ello y considerar una revisión previa con hablantes nativos para lograr una mayor fidelidad.

Aprovecho para preguntar: ¿sería posible habilitar en YouTube Music las mismas opciones de pista que ofrece YouTube tradicional? Sería ideal poder elegir entre idioma original y traducido.

Gracias y sigan con el gran trabajo!

comment_text:
I used to speak monotone, deep and slow.   When I got to college I got to listen to some really good lecturers.  A lot of them were bad, but a few were great communicators.   I started naturally emulating them I think without ever realizing I was doing it.  Through the years I’ve kept picking up different things from different people and 20 years later my communication and confidence level makes me content and comfortable in most situations.

I used to have to repeat myself often at work when I was younger.  When I learned to speak better, I started being seen as a leader.  It’s not just what you say, it’s also how you say it.

comment_text: In other words, you are using your 5 senses in oral communication. As a writer, I learned through trainings that I need to use my five senses when writing a novel or a book no matter what age group the audience is. If I want to engage the reader, I need to make the words come alive. So what I just learned is that we need to do the same when orally communicating.
author: @acts238believer1

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text: Excellent podcast! Thank you, Mr. Ving. You have a gift of being able to include visuals or experiences that people can relate to so that your point is understood deeper.
author: @acts238believer1

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text: I think by using melody, you make words come alive. And when using hand gestures to go with a melody, it’s as if those words become more intimate with the other person with whom we are communicating. As a result, you seem to be like a magnet that will draw others into your space, your time, and your relationship with them. But that a melody, can also keep people away because they don’t like the melody, right? So as a good communicator, I believe we need to be sensitive and observant of the individual with whom we need to communicate - especially during a particular situation or need that must be communicated. For example, if an individual was extremely upset and coming across very clearly with their words, body language,  tone, etc. m, one does not doubt the mood that they are in. So I as the recipient, would need be wise in how I react (tone and body language) in order to defuse their mood or anger. Powerful
author: @acts238believer1

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text: I have observed my own personal experience that my voice tones change because of who I am communicating with at the time. I was an introvert growing up. My personality was such as being laid-back. I married a high strong man who spoke loudly most of the time. He also lacked filters for the most part. He just blurted out whatever he came to his mind at that moment. I found myself having to smooth over if you will, the offense he had caused while speaking to someone. He would offend some people because of his straightforwardness and tone of voice. I was married to him nearly 40 years. But I saw myself becoming more like him when I communicated with him. My tone begin to rise higher, and I became very defensive, but only when talking to you. And then I noticed that I began to talk that way too individuals who treated me the same. And I dislike it very much.  What can I do to correct?

Knowing that he flew from Australia for this makes it harder for me to ask when will he come back because I know the logistics are extensive with travel but MAN this was absolutely phenomenal. I am invigorated after this talk and exited to start putting everything he mentioned into practice! His expressions are also beautiful to watch - I felt every single emotion he gave us. What a remarkable storyteller. I wonder if he teaches acting classes as well because actors are always communicating as well. This was just such an awesome episode. I’m geeked. ✨🙌🏽

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
1:41:00 “What do you do in your free time?” (To begin small talk).  

I loath the question “what do you DO?” It is an inherently judgemental question and I find most people want to put you in a box. As I’ve never fitted in a box, I hate answering it unless I’m with my own kind.

I replaced this question many years ago with “what do you do for fun?”

It’s a much more open question and allows people to talk about their special interests and hobbies (which are usually far more interesting to me). 

Occasionally I come across someone who has no interests outside of work. They can still answer by describing how they work for “fun”. 

However, I don’t feel obliged to reciprocate by sharing my profession.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
This is, imo, a disingenuous manipulation of communication, designed to take advantage of people and or situations. Trying to project yourself as something you're not or "become someone" to people to gain an advantage is disingenuous and manipulative. Especially when accompanied with hand gestures deliberately used to manipulate reception. Obviously this is NOT the motivation for everyone, but can be immensely destructive. These are tools of master manipulators. So you're teaching people how to manipulate other people with designed speech and mannerisms. So just as these are tools to use, They can be used incorrectly and destructively. I do believe.
It's important for people to speak effectively and appropriately.But I also feel like it's necessary to be genuine, not contrived.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
YO THERES CHANNELS THAT HAVE HELPED ME WITH THIS!!

I’ve had this issue all my life, two week ago though.. I started watching Vigh Giang (#1 communication expert in the world) 

I only saw like two small eight minute videos from him, and DAY. ONE. Instant relief.

————-

Get it out of your head that you’re going to put your internal experience out there perfectly to a T, we think in pictures thoughts images sounds and feelings and there’s no way you’re gunna put all of that out there in a sentence or even a full handful of sentences. This was my biggest hurdle.

—————-

People are always playing with their voices, and adjusting their tone and their tract playfully. You’re singing dude! To each other! Have fun using all the tones, the weird ones too, speaking isn’t meant to be a monotone discussion, HAVE FUN with your voice! 


Plus it was so expensive, why not use this newly shaped larynx?

———-

When you’re alone, say shit out loud. You need practice speaking what you actually feel, because you’re always capping and adjusting your statements to the people around you. This is why autistic folks with pets tend to be more outgoing and capable with speech!
————

Theodore Roosevelt had this tactic where WHILE he was listening, he’d formulate a response with his tongue to get a feel for what he wanted to actually say. It uses a different part of the brain (this one’s kinda difficult for me but just waffling it up and down tend to help as long as I think about the mouth movements.

///

Have fun with this!

comment_text: The English language has evolved to reflect and reinforce social class hierarchies. author: @jinnythomas9815

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text: As a Filipino immigrant who had been treated as less than equal because of my accent, I can speak to the fact that everything we do is nothing but a choice. Like Vihn I immediately found a way to overcome that by signing for a class on how to speak the american way. it wasn't so much as to not be who I was but so much more to be on the same playing field as everyone else. Yes I agree that some will live in foreign country for years but still have a heavy accent because they are afraid to 1. lose their identity. 2. being judged as ambitious (crab mentality) and 3. they dont know what they don't know (aka there is such thing as a speech pathologist). There is also the threat of losing the sense of belonging. when you immigrate to another country you know that you are not exactly American, British etc, so some parts of you know you don't belong there but you've been out of your country so long that you also no longer behave like people in your birth country. So you also don't feel like you belong in your birth country anymore. You then have to choose to continue your identity and be okay with it or you can choose to adapt a new identity and be okay with it too. Like Vihn choosing to speak like people in the new country and still keep my roots is something that has benefitted me tremendously.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text: I’m not here to diagnose anyone. As a late in life diagnosed neurodivergent person, Vinh’s way of breaking down communication and his ability to deeply drill down into human interactions and make them learnable is giving hyper focus and systemic thinking. Whether he identifies as neurodiverse himself or not, this is such an example of how thinking like this isn’t a disease or disability, but a gift to the rest of us. Breaking things down and making them more accessible.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
CEO Diary Vinh Giang Start 27 March 2025 Complete Monday 7th April 2025. Time Span 11 days.

Best Moments start here

Reality is negotiable
04:14 I have been able to negotiate an incredible reality. This is why I love Tim’s quote: reality is negotiable.

Story
50:00 When you pause, you are telling the other person to give a fuck about what you just said.
52:01 I will let my work speak for itself. Why not do both. Why not speak for your work. 

Mindset shift is
1:04:30 Mindset shift is I think about the audience. I only become self-conscious if I only think of myself. So I think of delivering value to them hence I don’t feel nervous.
1:05:20 so think of this as an act of service, there is no cognitive capacity to think about me. you are not self-conscious, you are audience-conscious.

Funny
1:07:00 don’t T-rex it

Very Funny
1:10:30 you are probably white / probably put on a bit of weight
1:10:48 computer- think pose- reason it is called this is I am processing what you are saying

Interesting moment of agreement and disagreement
1:18:20 I want to take it to the next level (but SB shakes his head in disagreement and shifts his eyes)

Articulation
1:21:30 I don’t believe accents are a problem. I believe articulation is. UK people are smart- James Bond- you articulate so well.
1:22:20 wrong mouth movements to speak new languages. He is born with the gift of gab, but reality is I was born gab-less. People say they speak with their hands in their pockets. Take hands out. It is just a behaviour.

Arena
1:30:06 if you are not in the arena with me, I am not interested- Brene Brown- Theodore Roosevelt

High low buffalo technique
1:34:25 high- I am on CEO now. Low- I don’t know what is enough. Buffalo-I have 3 alpacas. Now I have to beat the alpacas fact
1:36:56 I will go to my office in London to play high-low-buffalo
1:41:00 what do you do in your free time is a big Q

Funny
1:58:00 energy bribe

Raison D’etre
2:03:09 I want to get so good at teaching that I can help my son so much. He gives me eye contact.

Weird Suffering
2:05:20 mum and dad would buy a new car because uncle did. Someone would buy an apartment because uncle did. They bought a jet ski coz someone else did but they could not use it coz they don’t have a boat license.

Dad
2:10:45 good on him. It is not a phase. He wakes up each day free from attachments.
2:11:35 I was too deep in my keynote speaking career- it is such an addictive career- so financially rewarding. 80 speeches a year- this is 1 speech every 4 days. I was miserable. But you get paid so much. You think 1 more year, 1 more year. 
2:12:10 A king that knows the limits to his desires will rule the land.

Mindset Honesty
2:14:08 I never took time to sit still. This is why recalibrating trips are so honest. [wow]

Mindset how to talk = neutral ears
2:17:33 amazing process- find neutral ears. 
2:20:15 in the world we live, we can negotiate reality.
2:23:35 I call my students luminaries

Best Moments end here

comment_text:
All Moments start here

Reality is negotiable
04:14 I have been able to negotiate an incredible reality. This is why I love Tim’s quote: reality is negotiable.

Change
13:56 most people in life will never change how they communicate. They will change how they dress, their hair, their glasses, but not how they sound.
18:24 more volume, more melody, bigger hand gestures, people change the way they perceive them. 
19:20 Ah, it feels fake. No, it feels unfamiliar.

Melody

Feel and hear
27:40 Why is it worth it? You can make people feel what you are saying not just hear what you are saying.
30:20 People want focus. A big thing people want in their talking is clarity. How I say something is how you receive it. 

Reporting to reliving
44:00 reporting to re-living.

Story
45:30 hook-struggle-breakthrough-application. 
46:20 people love a good takeaway. We just keep consuming and go through knowledge acquisition. 
50:00 When you pause, you are telling the other person to give a fuck about what you just said.
52:01 I will let my work speak for itself. Why not do both. Why not speak for your work. 
53:20 record a video of you speaking for 5 minutes. Turn volume up. leave it for a day. If you watch it straight away, you are ugly, you don’t like the way you sound. Leave it for a day- you love the way you sound. Time and space, it is amazing.
54:20 people avoid filming themselves as they hate the way they look and sound.
55:50 you are not stuck- it is just a series of behaviours.
59:20 Kaizen- improvement- you do this here on your podcast

1:03:30 you spoke 80 times a year, this is 1 in 4 days, yeah it got a bit full on.

1:05:20 so think of this as an act of service, there is no cognitive capacity to think about me. you are not self-conscious, you are audience-conscious.

comment_text: 16:24 the reason newborns and toddlers don't lose their voice after screaming for a long time is not because they “have access to their natural voice”, its because their vocal folds are anatomically different from that of the adult. Their epithelium is thicker and the lamina propria is not fully developed as an adult’s, so the thicker and thus more resilient mucus layer protects their vocal folds from being damaged.

comment_text: @38:13 I am really not sure how men are being "taught" to keep their emotions on the inside that it is a sign of weakness to show sadness. While it may be really true but at least for the men around me, I don't agree that they were being taught. And I am talking about my own child. We never taught him this but he actually had a lot of suppressed emotions which we found out in recent years. Thankfully things have changed and we are so glad he shares nowadays. 🤩We do need to "ventilate", of course in a controlled way. It's scary walking around like some volcanoes that may go off suddenly. I think men being men usually don't say much including how they feel and what they are going through. It's just a man thing. Sometimes men are scarier than women 😂because you just don't know what they are thinking or feeling! My husband is also like this! comment_text:
Each day that I had time to watch this video, has given me time to reflect a little bit. Each story that Vinh gave, it was almost like I can feel the impact of it. It was like I was watching an old film. 

I like the “High Low Buffalo” segment. It sounded way more fun that just asking “how you’re doing,” or some boring small talk. 

I hear a lot of my friends say “yes but,” and I’ve not once heard a “yes and.” Maybe once, but they’re not a bad friend. I never thought about it as a conversation ender. Sometimes I cringe a bit when I hear someone, a friend, or a family member say “yes but.” It hurts a little more when a family member says “yes but.” 

This has been a great video to watch! Thank you for sharing!

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
26:26 holy FUCK Steven, that was so well done! I got goosebumps! 

This is exactly what I learned in drama class in high school. Our teach made us read these famous monologues out loud, one by one, a couple times. First time- she dictated how we are to inflect our voices (high, low, fast, slow, giggling, sobbing) without prior notice. She would just shout out, and we would have to follow it immediately. Then the whole thing again but with just her hand gestures, and we would have to interpret on the fly what we thought she meant. No wrong answers, and sometimes it would result in absolutely hilarious moments because she would play with us to get us to break. Then, we would take 5min in the back room (while she did the same to someone else) to really think about what we were saying, and how we felt at each point in the sentence. And when it came to our turn again, we would be speaking from the heart - full of emotion, differences in tone and speed and volume, depending on each word and how it ties into the sentence and then into the monologue as a whole. It made for some of the most memorable scenes, and not all of them are the same as the original. Which is exactly what our teacher wanted. She wanted us to say the monologues as if WE were the ones who said it first, and that it was not scripted. 

It definitely wasn’t easy, and it took me a couple months to get comfortable enough with the sound of my own voice to learn how to play with it. But if it wasn’t for her, I never would’ve known how much fun it is to read with my child.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
This comment summarizes key takeaways from a video about improving public speaking skills. The main points include:

1. Biggest Mistake – A monotone voice makes speakers forgettable. Vocal variety keeps listeners engaged.


2. Improving Voice – Use volume changes, melody, pauses, and speech rate variation.


3. Emotion in Speech – Facial expressions influence vocal tone, making speech more engaging.


4. Why Some Get Ignored – Low volume and flat tone make speakers seem unconfident. Confident speakers pause, project, and control the room.


5. Fixing a Boring Voice – The "Siren Technique" expands vocal range, making speech more dynamic.


6. Speaking Style as a Habit – Your current voice is learned, but it can be retrained within 3–6 months.


7. Confidence for Introverts – Confidence is a skill, not a personality trait. Train to speak louder, use gestures, and pause more.


8. Persuasive Speaking – Adjust speech pace, volume, and gestures for authority and engagement.


9. Why Loud People Succeed – Confidence is perceived as competence. Learn to project confidence vocally.


10. Avoiding Fake Voices – Over-rehearsed or robotic tones make speakers sound inauthentic.


11. Memorable Voices – Melody and variety make voices stand out.


12. Emotional Impact – Tone matters more than words in making people feel something.


13. Great Storytelling – Instead of just stating facts, use details, emotions, and sensory descriptions.


14. Power of Pauses – Pauses strengthen emotions and emphasize key points.


15. Fixing Speaking Habits – The "Record & Review" method helps identify areas for improvement.


16. Avoid Overwhelming Fixes – Focus on improving one vocal element per week for steady progress.


17. Why Communication Matters – Skilled speakers get ahead more than skilled workers. Work on vocal delivery as much as technical skills.


18. Projecting Confidence – Controlling speech pace and volume makes speakers seem more authoritative.


19. Holding Attention – Pauses and emotional contrast keep listeners engaged.


20. Why Most Don't Improve – Many assume their voice is unchangeable, but it's a learned skill.


21. Owning the Room – Vocal changes, intentional pauses, and emphasis make speech powerful.



Final Challenge: Pick one habit to improve and practice daily. Confident communication opens doors in all areas of life.

2:17:35  Hãy tìm 1 nơi có những Neutral ears (tức là những người ko hề có khái niệm j về mình, và họ cũng ko quá quan tâm về mình) rồi PLAY with your voice, with your body language. 💌 Nơi đó có thể là 1 tiệm tạp hóa ở xa nhà, hoặc chỗ đổ xăng lạ lạ mà mình ít khi nào tới.

🤎 Càng nhiều những thay đổi mà KO BỊ PHÁN XÉT, các hành động thay đổi đó sẽ ở lại lâu hơn 1 chút. Cho đến 1 lúc nó trở thành 1 phần của mình luôn.

🤧 Có KPIs mỗi ngày càng tốt, mỗi ngày mình sẽ PLAY càng nhiều càng tốt. Bởi vì những lần đầu làm sẽ rất là ghê, nhưng qua nhiều lần làm, mình sẽ rút kinh nghiệm dần dần 🤗

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
Notes I’ve taken from this episode:

1. Learn to speak with pauses to emphasize the words you’re saying. Pauses in sentences create suspense and lure your audience into what you’re about to say next.  

2. Speak with different volumes—it can be quiet or loud depending on the situation. This helps eliminate monotone and creates emotion.  

3. Most of us tend to speak at a volume of 3-4 out of 10. Try to bring that up to 5-6 and enunciate your words properly. The goal of speaking is for the other party to understand what you’re saying.  

4. Replace filler words like “uh,” “um,” and “like” with pauses. Learn to be comfortable with pauses within your talk.  

5. Use Grok or GPT to generate a 5-minute conversation starter. Video record yourself talking about the topic and watch it the next day—don’t watch it immediately after so you can stay neutral.  

You’ll want to watch the video 3 times:  
First time, just listen and notice how you talk—note down improvements you can make and work on them.  

Second time, turn the volume off and watch how you talk to understand your visual representation.  

Third time, run it through a transcription tool to identify your filler words and word choices.
Practice a lot! Your friends and family might judge you when you start changing how you talk. Practice with strangers—maybe at a gas station out of your way or with an Uber driver.  

6. It’s not a quick process. It takes the best students 3-6 months, but the result is blissful. Being able to communicate well is an unfair advantage.  

7. Don’t let your present dictate your future self. Give your future self a chance to be better. Be uncomfortable until you’re comfortable.
author: @SLPC_

I’ve never understood ‘list’ note taking. It’s like something to learn to do; a formula that one incorporates to appear differently than we do naturally or did before. 
This video is more about communicating and communication at its base level is empathetic with listener from the place within where our true beliefs reside. 

External things we offer verbally even if we conquered our presentation nuances by this list is essentially acting. It’s not a conversation with our audience. Not trying to be mean but I saw the summary list and felt deflated. 
15:29- 16:49 there’s a big difference between merely being genuine and affected passion. Being genuine is highly influential.

Steven, please don't make any changes in your interview style. Your pronunciation is clear. Your speech is neither too slow nor too fast. Your interview style is spot on. Steven, some of your super powers that make your channel so interesting and comfortable to watch is that you are such a great listener and give your guests your undivided attention. You never make the  interview about yourself. Just imagine, their approach to this interview is switched, how bizarre it would be to have someone to ask questions in a different "notes" (as Vinh would put), and have someone reply to the interviewer in a monotone on the topic of communication skills.    It's all down to 1 word "context".  They are just playing their roles.
author: @m1615hk

comment_text:
1:33:25 Halo Buffalo techhniche - đc dùng để bắt chuyện, nhưng là kiểu bắt chuyện để connect sâu sắc, chứ ko phải kiểu small talk nha: 

- Ha: sth is going great about your life.
- Lo: sth bother you, or you are struggling with,...
- Buffalo: sthing interesting about yourself.

💪 But it take courage to do it 💪 Và cách này khá hay vì nó đưa ra 3 cầu nối lận, sẽ có ít nhất 1 cầu nối giúp mình connect đc ❤

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text: When I was 14 years old, my church paid for me to go to a Sunday School teacher's workshop. I took the storytelling class. I was taught how to use my voice, eyes, and body to be effective as a storyteller. (This was maybe 1974.) At first, I felt SO awkward! I learned how to make a child's voice, a mommy voice, and a man's voice. I was terrified to try it out in class with the kids. Their response was immediate! I have continued to work on this and have enjoyed the effectiveness that it brings to my classroom.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
53:02 3 bước xử lý sau khi nhận ra các vấn đề về giao tiếp: 

🗣  Record 1 video dài 5' mà về nội dung ngẫu nhiên nhen, chứ ko phải những nội dung mình nói về quá nhiều lần. Rồi đợi 1 ngày sau. 

🤧 Review bằng các forms khác nhau: 
- Nghe lại: chỉ nghe, và tự đánh giá xem giọng mình như nào (dựa vào foudations). 
- Nhìn lại body language: tắt âm đi rồi coi lại. Mình sẽ thấy những động tác mình hay làm trong vô thức. 
- Nghe xem từ ngữ mình xài: có non words và filler words nào ko. 

🗣 Note lại đầy đủ và bắt đầu chỉnh sửa từng thứ. Lưu ý: chỉnh sửa TỪNG chỗ 1. Ví dụ tuần 1 mình sửa chỗ nói chậm quá (bằng cách nói nhanh lên, chừng nào tốc độ mình cải thiện rồi thì ok, mất bao lâu ko quan trọng bằng việc mình cải thiện đc), tuần tiếp theo mình sửa chỗ ấp úng,...
author: @thamphan5884

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
20:44 Vocal image - khi họ nghe đc giọng mình, họ sẽ bắt đầu có những believes nào đó về mình. 

- Pitch và Melody 21:41 : you have a melody in your voice 😮
 
 + Siren techniche: làm theo để  hiểu là chúng ta có rất nhiều nốt nhạc mà chúng ta thường ko xài. Nếu mình làm lố quá lố thì ngta sẽ phản ứng lại (thà là làm lố, còn hơn là làm ko tới nha). 

 + Rate of speech 29:03 : trên thang điểm từ 1 tới 10, nếu muốn highlight a point thì nên nói chậm lại. Còn nếu muốn 1 chút charisma (hoặc những filling word) thì có thể nói nhanh lên. Nói chung là trong đoạn hội thoại, tốc độ nói của mình nên chuyển biến, nhấn nhá liên tục chứ ko nên giữ nguyên 1 tốc độ. Vì giữ nguyên từ đầu tới cuối thì người nghe sẽ chán.

 + Volume 33:57 : khá quan trọng, vì volume nó sẽ gánh cho melody, tốc độ,.... Để highlight j đó, mình sẽ nói nhỏ nhẹ lại. Nhưng nếu nói nhỏ liên tục thì ngta sẽ cảm thấy mình tự ti. Và nếu nói lớn liên tục mà ko kết hợp các yếu tố trên (melody, speech,...) ngta sẽ cảm thấy mình ngạo mạo.

 + Tonality 36:46 : là emotion của giọng mình. Để thêm nhiều emtion vô giọng mình là đưa biểu hiện của gương mặt vô. Và khi người đối diện nhìn thấy khuôn mặt mình, họ sẽ cảm nhận đc cảm xúc đó luôn 😮. *Có thể xem lại các cues của Vanessa*.

 + Story telling 43:41 : phải reliving the story (chứ ko phải reporting kiểu who, where, when, why). Và công thức là VAKS (Visual, Auditory, Kinesthetic, and Smell). 

 + Pause 48:27 : cứ mỗi lần mình pause 1 cái, cảm xúc liền trước đó sẽ được nhấn mạnh thêm. Và cái pause cũng sẽ cho người nghe 1 time để xử lý những j mình vừa kể.

comment_text: Great convo! When Vinh talked about trying out a new voice on "neutral ears", I had to smile. I am a 72-year-old extreme introvert and tend to be reserved and rather serious. Then, a few weeks ago, I was invited to a party and decided to try on a new persona. A man I had not seen in a long time came up to me and asked how I was. Instead of saying, "I'm fine. How are you?", I smiled at him and said, "John, my dear, I'm absolutely fantastic! Thank you for asking. I hope life is treating you well." That led into a fun, playful conversation that set the tone for the rest of the evening. I was actually rather amazed how easy it was to become the person I chose to be.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
This conversation had me hanging on every word...
Vinh's story about his son was so powerful. He became a communication expert for his son, and yet feels torn with his success and being away from his family. I really appreciated the raw and authentic discussion of the different pulls in our lives and the challenge it is to balance and focus on the things that really matter.  I also really liked the discussion on having different vocal confidence in different situations. It gave me context in my own life as I am confident talking to one person- yet in a group I have a hard time saying anything at all and my vocal confidence can be very low. I feel like in a group my words are less valuable than other people- so I let them talk. Now I have more tools to improve my communication.  Thank you for this- one of the best videos I have seen from this channel so far!
author: @andreacasavant3506

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
Summary for people too lazy to watch the whole video:

This video features a conversation between Steven Bartlett and Vinh Giang, an award-winning speaker and communication expert who teaches people how to harness the power of their voice and body language. The discussion focuses on how anyone can improve their communication skills and transform their life through specific techniques and practices.

Key Points:

1. Voice as an Instrument
- Giang emphasizes that our voice is like a musical instrument that can be played with different techniques
- He introduces five core foundations of vocal communication: melody, rate of speech, volume, tonality, and pauses
- These elements can be learned and practiced to become a more effective communicator

2. Breaking Communication Barriers
- Most people believe they're stuck with their current communication style, but this is a limiting belief
- Communication skills can be dramatically improved in 3-6 months with proper practice
- Technical skills alone aren't enough; they must be paired with strong communication abilities

3. Practical Techniques
- The "Record and Review" method: Record yourself speaking, wait a day, then review it three ways (audio only, video only, and transcript)
- Use the "Power Sphere" (area between belly button and eyes) for more effective gesturing
- Implement the FORD framework (Family, Occupation, Recreation, Dreams) for better conversations
- Practice with "neutral ears" (strangers) before introducing new communication styles to familiar relationships

4. Cultural and Personal Identity
- Communication styles are learned behaviors, not fixed traits
- The concept of "contextual confidence" explains why people may communicate better in certain situations
- Cultural sensitivity is important when adapting communication styles across different contexts

Important Takeaways:

1. Communication improvement requires:
- Regular practice and self-assessment
- Willingness to step outside comfort zones
- Understanding that change feels uncomfortable at first

2. Better communication leads to:
- Improved professional opportunities
- Stronger personal relationships
- Greater influence and presence
- Enhanced ability to express ideas and connect with others

3. Practical Implementation:
- Start with one technique at a time
- Practice in low-stakes situations
- Gradually incorporate new skills into daily life
- Be patient with the learning process

The conversation concludes with Giang's concept of "luminaries" - people who understand that life presents different stages requiring different communication approaches. He emphasizes that by mastering communication skills, individuals can better navigate these various roles and make a positive impact through their interactions with others.

This discussion provides both theoretical understanding and practical tools for improving communication skills, making it valuable for anyone looking to enhance their personal or professional relationships through better communication.
Key Points:
* Voice as Communication Instrument
* Record and Review Method
* Cultural and Personal Confidence
* Improving Small Talk

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
I stumbled across Vinh's teachings on YouTube Shorts a couple of years ago, and they truly changed my life. As an immigrant living in the US, I was always self-conscious about my accent. I turned down major speaking opportunities—even when they were about topics I’m deeply passionate about and gifted in—because of that inner doubt.

But through Vinh's guidance, I shifted that mindset. I ended up giving a keynote address that literally moved a nation. Today, I’m a correspondent on Live TV with my own segment. The limiting identities I once held could have blocked me from these opportunities—but I applied Vinh's teachings and transformed my life.

I still chuckle on the inside when people refer to me as a sought-after speaker. Never in my wildest dreams did I imagine this would be my story. Thank you, Vin. Truly.

Steven, I've only recently started listening to your podcast and it's only been a couple, but... I want to thank you so so much for this incredible thing you're doing. comment_text:
Tưởng tượng mình là 1 người chơi piano đi, nếu mình thường chơi những nốt trầm thì mình sẽ mặc định những nốt trầm là cách chơi từ lúc đẻ ra rồi, ko đổi đc. Nhưng thực ra thì mình gán cho nó là "từ lúc đẻ ra" chỉ vì nó là những nốt mình THƯỜNG XUYÊN chơi thôi. Và mình vẫn chơi những nốt cao đc mà, chỉ là chưa quen thôi!

Việc thay đổi giọng nói, tính cách cũng vậy. Mình thường mặc định giọng nói hiện tại là có từ lúc đẻ ra tới giờ. Nhưng thật ra chỉ là vì mình quen xài kiểu giọng nói, tính cách này thôi!

_ Ví dụ 18:45 : lý do mình hay ngại nói là vì: mình quen lặp đi lặp lại hành vi ngại quá nhiều năm trên đời rồi. Nó là điều dễ hiểu thôi. Và trở nên tự tin hơn cũng là việc quen với 1 chuỗi các hành vi làm mình tự tin trong 1 khoảng time đủ dài.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
This is so true, we can change our voices!

After I developed a painful speech disorder, I spent a few months with a speech-language pathologist to relearn how to speak using a different part of my face (resonant) to take pressure off my vocal chords. She talked a lot about cultural speech patterns, how we learn to speak by imitating those around us. She even had me doing exercises with a British accent pretending I was Mary Poppins, which used the correct (not painful) part of my mouth and face to create the sound. My kids thought it was pretty funny at home that my new voice was British, LOL! Eventually I forced my American accent back in, but my new voice is still very recognizable, my public speaking is dramatically improved from a more varied and melodic technique, no more pain, and bonus I can sing now!

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
Thank you for this.

I'd like to weigh in on the "but it's not me" statement. I would argue that learning to play your instrument - i.e. control how you sound - would get one closer to being themselves, not further away. Especially in social situations, where oftentimes we get so anxious that we resort to that monotone voice, don't know what to do with our hands, think about a hundred things at a time. In my experience, being anxious has been embarrassingly in a way of sounding truthful. Sometimes I might be sharing my innermost thought, something that comes right from my heart, but because I am already uncomfortable, and also am worrying about how people will react to it - all of a sudden my voice is high, I blush, I fidget. That makes me look like such a liar, which makes me worry even more, so without any pause for other people's reaction I start answering the hostile questions that haven't been asked. So this whole sharing of my truth didn't go the way it sounded in my mind at all. 
I think that finding a bit more of one's own voice (which, as Vinh has said during this conversation, is lost at age 2 or 3) and mastering it to the point that one can carry it into the social situation - that would in fact help one feel more like "it's me", more like they are bringing themselves into the room, not their learned or automatic reactions, but their true selves.
author: @anchoussha

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
This is my first time commenting on your channel, and I just have to say—every piece of information here is so valuable that I kept pausing, thinking, and replaying to connect the dots. I usually listen to podcasts while jogging in the morning, but this one was so insightful that I had to come back home, put it on again, and listen carefully to every word.

One of my biggest takeaways was how your voice can truly impact the way a message is received—and it doesn’t have to sound fake while doing so. We often worry that changing our voice might make us sound unnatural, but the way Vinh explained it here really showed how powerful and authentic it can be.

Thanks for creating this! Would love to hear from others—what was your biggest takeaway from this episode?
author: @sj_ghotra

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text: I recently screamed in unbelievable levels of agony for 16 hours straight. My voicebox was injured after all that, naturally, but yeah its been six months and my doctor believes my vocal cords are so  scarred their shape is different, maybe scarred for life, and ever since that night my voice has become a few octaves higher than it’s ever been in my adult life. It’s been very hard to cope with not sounding like myself, and I speak in this annoying high pitch now, especially if I’m excited, and the more excited the higher the pitch. It’s downright creepy. . . To not recognize your own voice. And trying to speak lower, my voice is even more unrecognizable, and it weirds me out so much I stop trying.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
He actually repeats words/stutters in replacement of “uh” and “um”.

Listen closely and you can hear he does say “and… and” or “I… I”.
He says it very quickly but doing this actually serves the same purpose as saying “um” or “uh”. It’s called a filler word or vocalised pause.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text: Public speaking isn’t just about what you say—it’s about how you make people feel. Confidence, vocal tone, strategic pauses, and emotional delivery all shape the way people perceive you. Vinh Giang is right: mastering communication isn’t a talent, it’s a skill that can be sharpened. But here’s a thought—how much of effective speaking is technique, and how much is authenticity? Do people connect more with polished delivery or raw, genuine emotion?

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
Practical Action: 

🎤 The “Record & Review” Method for Instant Improvement (1:15:00 - 1:20:00)

[thanks to @shdwza]

Step 1: Record yourself speaking for 5 minutes (impromptu, no script)

Step 2: Audio Review – Listen with the screen off. 
Analyze:
- Volume: Too quiet? Too loud?
- Melody: Too flat? Engaging enough?
- Rate: Rushing or dragging?

Step 3: Visual Review – Watch the video on mute. 
Notice:
Posture & body language.
Hand gestures – Too stiff or too wild?
Facial expressions – Engaged or blank?

Step 4: Transcript Review – Read your words 
Highlight:
- Filler words ("um, like, you know")
- Rambling – Are your points clear and concise?

Step 5: Pick ONE thing to improve per week (rate, pauses, tone, etc.).

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text: I sometimes feel the length of these videos are a tad overwhelming to get hooked into only because I have other things to do in my day, maybe a bite size version would be a good alternative to the longer versions at times, although I know the content will be awesome. This however, really gripped me the entire length. One of my faves, great speaker. I only wish my cognitive ability to think shit up on the spot was better, like answering questions with speed and clarity, and wit, that moment where you always review a situation and wish you said something in the moment and you didn’t but then play the scenario on how it should have gone etc. Maybe something I can get better in time with some types of practice? Or is this something you reckon your IQ, or brain speed will always define. It’s weird as well, because, at times my brain is in an environment where I will be on fire with responses because I’m not nervous, or because I’m relaxed, or I’m with people I know or the crowd matches me in a lot of ways and they feel receptive, or I’m a tiny bit more tipsy. So maybe it is down to removing nervousness, being more confident, fixating less on yourself, redirecting nerves. But I do feel my ability to elaborate or think of the right words, or how to explain things really holds me back at times unless I really mull it over. Maybe something to bring Vinh on to speak about again if he has any insight on this side of things 🙏

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
Steven, I truly appreciate The Diary of a CEO—your intelligent communication and interviewing skills add so much to the learning experience. The depth of the conversations and the insights shared are invaluable.

That said, the frequent use of strong language, especially the F-bomb, is both distracting and unnecessary. As much as I enjoy the content, I find it impossible to share the podcast with family, friends, or colleagues who would greatly benefit from it. And that’s a shame, because your message is powerful and deserves to reach as many people as possible.

I believe you’re better than the status quo—those who rely on expletives because they lack the vocabulary to engage their audience. You have the intelligence and skill to captivate without it, and I hope you’ll consider making the podcast more family-friendly. It would only expand its reach and impact! Thank you

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
If you could fix me, you would fix anyone...  My issue is not so much in how i say things, volume, gestures, etc... it is more of "what" i say...  and this is a couple things.


First, i have a terrible time trying to explain things that i know.  For example, let's say i have solved a problem that has been preventing a product from performing the way it should.  However the problem requires some explanation...  and i somehow struggle greatly with coming up with the words that help others understand.  

So it becomes the case that I "actually" know an answer that the team is looking for, but in the wind of everyone saying, "it's this, it's that..." my submission is only just another one in the sea of ideas and suggestions.  

But time is limited, space, money, parts, etc... so it is not uncommon that my initial ideas get passed by very quickly.  However as is often the case, there is a lot on the line, and i "know that i am right" (and here i mean technically, and i mean for real) yet no one is listening to me, i get dismissed easily, quickly.    If asked for info when i first get the chance i can start to "fall behind" myself, tripping over words, taking things out of sequence, just mistakes like these i guess.

Then as days/weeks/or even months go by as i try over and over people become "tired" of hearing me speak -  "Not this again" is the kind of pushback i would see.  

Please know that this is not because i "think" i am smart (i am sorta smart for sure, usually can keep up with what is going on, but i am nothing special tbh - just an oddly good problem solver), this is not because i communicate on such a high level that no one can understand because of the sophisticated words, not at all), but i actually can solve the problem everyone is working on.  

Even when i have brought physical proof of the solution I had it was often not enough - why - because of the damage that i have done to my reputation by coming across confusing over and over.  And this is not limited to problem solving, it can extend to any conversation, technical or not.  Usually it is when there is some tension in the air i think, that does tighten me up...  Even here i do not think i have clearly got my point across.  

Anyway, this is already a ton of typing which is a turn of in itself so i will just stop and see if anyone has something helpful.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
THe big issue with this is that he proposes that you sort of need to imagine this personalit you come want become and basically act that way for so long untill you do not without thinking about it. However, the problem is that you loose authenticity in adapting towards some idea you have. My girlfriend is  naturally very, very expressive, has lots of facial epressions when she talks, moves her hands constantly and evne makes symbols of the things she says. She says she just does this naturally. Well, the thing is that it fits her natural personaly because she expresses who she is inside. I am on the other hand pretty monotone in how I sound, I have little facial expressions and talk much more rationally. However, whereas I certainly see that if you are on some sort of stage doing some stuff its helpful I would advice against really incorporating this deeply in your own system, as it will mean you will attract people whoare interested in the persona you present as rather than the real you. My girlfriend is basically exclusively attracted to guys who are LOW on expression, LOW on extraversion and all of htese htings, casue that is her opposite. She has an abundance of that extrverted emotional expressive energy, but she seeks introverred and rational energy. SHe's constantly moving, so  shef feels attracted to calm guys. All her bfs before me were calm too, cuase she does not find guys that act liek her attractive at all. It's like this with most couples. Not exactly the way me and my gf are devided, as you can also be introverted and a feeler and then you feel attracted to extraverted and a more rational person. People really do feel most attracted to their opposites to create a spark.
So sure, if you want to use such things at your job cause its useful there , sure. However, you will not attract the crowd who is interested in poeple like you whether its romantic partners or friends. Some people want to feel ackknowleged so they become want to become famous and be seen by everyone and hope to feel btter about themselves...hwoever, suually they do not. ALso, ltos of their fans are fans of their image and not the real them. So now they have 2 problems. Who likes oyu and who lieks oyu cause you';re rich and famous?
I do not try to dismiss the usefulness of knowing some techniques like this, but I would not think it is a good idea to really incorporate it too deeply in yourself, as it will yield short term benefits, but long term problems.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
So, correct me if i am wrong, in order to change your vocal repetoire, you need to replace yourself with someone you are not, you adopt a new identity? 
And here i come from a point of learning where it was made very clear to me that replacing yourself with someone you are not could often lead to cognitive disorder, dissociative personality disorder which could lead to narcistic personality disorder. Narcissistic people are often very charismatic and initially welcoming, enjoyable to be around.  

Interestingly enough when i skipped past the introduction (which is a repeat of something that will be seen later in the vod) to the actual start of the talk the first thing that came to mind is, fake. 
Then again, continuing to listen i can admit that Vinh comes across as very endearing, he clearly knows how to use his voice to open you up for reception, however his facial expressions continue to misalign in my head, they seem forced even, so what then? I am sure we can pick up things that can benefit us, however i can't step away from the fact that if you are a certain way, moulded by your environment through external factors, as Vinh explains how he was invisible in his early childhood, children ignored or even bullied him, this leaves trauma, that people should not cover this with something that is a mask, a puppet, a new skin, that this should not be covered by "a new identity", faking it till you are making it, will leave you stranded in illusion and a fantasy. 

I myself have masked myself, to hide the negatives of childhood, to "be another person" as a coping mechanism, this granted me attention, however this did not solve what needed solving, heal what needed healing. 
Through my cope i was treated a certain way, i interacted with my environment, expressing myself in a way that was not me. 
We all want to be seen, even those who think they want to be invisible, who retreat themselves from society, would prefer companionship, just not the pain that often comes with this. 
Btw, companionship could come in the form of something ethereal or imagined, however this is another topic. 

I do think the music teacher, which Vinh narrates as her plinking on a single key for 2 minutes, asking him how it made him feel and then playing a song, and asking him again how it made him feel, and her teaching him that most people go through life only by speaking/plinking that one key, that she is teaching something profound. The great divide i see is Vinh using the term "adopting a new identity", true, he also states that he helps people, him saying "tuning the piano", yet i can't ignore those subtle nudges towards this whole "adopting a new identity". 
The fact which remains is that the lady showed him 1 piano, with all its black and white keys, the piano did not change, the piano did not adopt a new identity. The piano was monotonous when having but 1 key plinked, yet that same key was being used when she played the whole song. No new identity was adopted, the identity of the piano stayed the same, with all its years of service, the potential scratches on it, the paint maybe flecking off somewhere not quickly seen by the eye, the dust that covered the snares and hidden corners and crevices, the spider that made its nest in there, some snares that may have been replaced over the years. The piano did not change, it already contained all the potential, there was no need to bring in a new piano, to completely remake the piano. The woman who played the piano did not change either, she was the agent and the piano was her voice in this case. 

This is what i take away from this story, we have the voice, though do we have the agency, do we have the peace to express it as such.
And for those who are struggling with elements from ones past, do we have the right people in our lives that are strengthening us, provide us with cold water to refresh ourselves and hot water to sooth ourselves with. 
Interactions and experiences which would heal the broken string, the muffled sound, the scratches, the paint flecking and cleans out the rags and dust. 
People who Love, instead of people who want.
author: @arqeph.private

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text: I love this conversation, and I am definitely a big fan of Vinh. But I wish you would have sat in the conversation about the survey about discrimination in speech. Because the answer Vinh gave, "articulation" is something we call code switching in the US. I would love to hear this hashed out. Like when you spoke about your Mom, he mentioned she keeps her Nigerian accent for a link to identity. But, as an African American I have spoken English my entire life. So, the message is still the same. You must speak like a certain type of person and distance yourself from your identity to be perceived as intelligent.
author: @AliveInYah

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text: Confidence is a feeling not a set of behaviours. Acting confident vs feeling confident are two very different things. One is based on having a facade and the other is based on a genuine soul based emotional change that a person undergoes where they automatically feel confident vs putting on an act.
author: @ellatronixofficial

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang

author: @avo5499

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
@@avo5499 Its sth like fake it till u make it. Acting confident vs feeling confident are all a simple thing about belief. If u believe u can will and must be confident, then your mind follows that drive. At first it will false, a lie and a rationalization. However over time this act will solidify into a habit until u one day feel confident. Confidence usually brings positive results. These results solidify the habit until it becomes "you". 
 
It is possible but very difficult.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
52:49

Key calls-to-action: 
1. Record a 5-minute video impromptu (while standing) speaking behaviors and leave it for a day. 
2. Turn the sound all the way up and just listen to your voice. Turn the sound all the way down and only see the video and watch your body language. You're not stuck. 
3. Get it transcribed. See if you ramble? Find out your unique filler words, etc. and remove those clutter words from your language moving forward.

comment_text: My daughter (30) is autistic and we have tried to work with her on her voice for YEARS, since she was a little girl.  It is her voice——monotone and loud—-that reveals her disability, otherwise people would not know she is autistic (or it would be more difficult).  She gets very offended/irritated when we remind her about her volume…..and when you said, “that’s not me” is her typical response.  😢

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text: Thank you for having him on! I am a person who stutters and I am trying to improve my communication skills. I'm trying to improve in fluency (different than just public speaking, it's the mechanics of speech that "normal" people don't even think about) and my overall communication skills. Most people don't understand that to a person who stutters, something as simple as telling someone your name can be an extreme emotional roller-coaster, filled with shame, self loathing, anger, and more. (God forbid you get asked to repeat yourself 😂😂) Learning more techniques like are taught in this podcast slowly help me have more fluent days and confidence in speech. So thank you for putting out this information for free - some of us may need it more than you know.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
I really enjoyed this video. It kept me engaged and laughing at times.😇

In my teenage years, I used to be very anxious, sweating and blanking out while talking. Major reason being that I was labeled as a shy child. Getting my first part-time job as a waitress really pushed me to be less serious, playful, loud, confident with my voice,etc. It really got me out of my inability to connect to others. 

I saw one comments saying that "he sounds fake." while I completely see the opposite. To captivate others and connect to others takes skill. Once you start mastering it, you will see that it becomes a part of you. Its just another way to express yourself; often in a more positive way that also earns positive feedback. "You are just unfamiliar with the key" (-VINH). What one may deem as authentic could just be the key that you have been playing your whole life. Whats to say being bright🌟isn't your other side of authenticity. You can be both at different times, a person that can be fun and full of life can also be genuine and a good friend.✨

I am still not where I want to be, so I will keep learning💗 So I find this video and his message fascinating!

Detailed Report: Public Speaking Mistakes That Make People Ignore You (And How to Fix Them)

Introduction

Vin J., a communication and public speaking expert, shares powerful strategies to improve speaking skills and avoid mistakes that make people ignore or disengage. His advice is based on personal experience and proven techniques that enhance vocal and physical presence.

Common Mistakes and How to Fix Them

1. Your Voice as a Musical Instrument

- Pitch Variety

Your voice isn’t just a tool—it’s an instrument. Use different tones to express emotions (e.g., excitement, sadness, suspense).

Siren Technique: Shift your voice from low to high tones within a sentence to grab attention.

- Vocal Control

Volume Control: Alternate between loud and soft tones to emphasize key points.

Speaking Pace: Speed up for energy, slow down for emphasis.

2. Body Language: The Key to Confidence

- Using Large Gestures

Use expansive hand movements within your "energy sphere" (the area between your navel and eyes) to project confidence.

Avoid small, closed-off gestures, like keeping your hands close to your body ("T-Rex arms").

- Facial Expressions Matter

Your face is a "remote control" for emotions. Practice exaggerated expressions (joy, anger, surprise) to make your message more engaging.

3. Overcoming Social Anxiety and Fear of Speaking

- The Record & Review Method

Record yourself speaking for 5 minutes, then analyze:

Voice: Are you using pitch variety?

Body Language: Are your gestures dynamic?

Speech Clarity: Are you using too many filler words ("um," "like")?

- Adopting a New Identity

Replace old habits (e.g., speaking softly) with confident behaviors (e.g., projecting your voice) to rewire your self-image.

4. Success Stories: From Invisible to Unstoppable

- Vin’s Personal Story

Bullied for his accent ("FOB" – Fresh Off the Boat), he mastered English pronunciation and body language to become a global speaker.

- Rachel’s Transformation

Once labeled "shy," she developed executive presence by using larger gestures and vocal variety.

Actionable Tips for Immediate Improvement

✅ Master Your Vocal "Instrument":

Read a sentence aloud, experimenting with pitch (low → high → low).

✅ Practice Bold Gestures:

Read a children’s book with exaggerated movements and notice engagement.

✅ Break Social Barriers with "High-Low-Buffalo":

Start conversations using this improv game: 

High: A recent success.

Low: A current challenge.

Buffalo: A quirky fact about yourself.

Conclusion

Effective public speaking is not an inborn talent—it’s a skill developed through:

Vocal variety to engage listeners.

Confident body language to command presence.

Consistent practice to replace old habits.

Start today: Record a video, identify one improvement (e.g., louder voice), and track your progress over 3–6 months.

Inspiration:

"Reality is negotiable. To become a powerful communicator, you must learn to play your instrument masterfully." — Vin J.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
I just finished watching this video and it was amazing. It really struck me in a place that hurt. I have done well with the ways I have communicated in the past, but I seem to be lacking now.

Something that I thought about, after listening, was that my thoughts, and the things I say to myself, have all of the aspects of something I would say if a cathartic response and experience was the goal. I think that this for me has been rather positive, but in many cases it can be incredibly negative. For example: "Why would you really think you're worth anything? (Long pause) It's obvious you don't have value." Speaking slowly while saying why, you, worth anything, obvious, and value. While speaking louder while saying you in the second phrase and quieter while saying anything at the end. 

I'm recognizing that if I communicated to others the way I thought to myself, I could have a greater impact. That there isn't an inherent brain to voice connection.

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text: I think a lot of people don't want to change their accents or linguistic patterns because they think they are being untrue to their own origins.  My Czech parents had no such feeling about their speaking English.  I was so proud of my father using difficult words in the proper way; my mother was able to work in Canada's major jewellery store.  I grew up in Canada and my Canadian-born sister later emigrated to Australia and became an ABC producer of a 30-program on religions - she was granted the Governor-General Award in that area in 2018.  In the States, Ebophonics was touted as a viable language pattern that Afro-Americans could and should use.  It backfired.  I look at the amazing black actors such as Sidney Poitier, Morgan Freeman, James Earl Jones who became heart-throbs and lovable people because they used the language to their purpose and the rest is history.

comment_text: I am only 17 minutes in and intrigued!  His discussion of losing our natural voices when we are young as we learn through imitating those closest to us to create the voices we then learn are our own reminds me of something I heard years ago.  A study showed that the way that British people smile is different from how Americans do it.  I mean the way that the muscles in the face move into a smile is different!  How interesting.  The researchers surmised that babies look into their parents’ faces and imitate expressions, as well as apparently how to get there.  Now, back to your podcast!  😍

comment_text: This is brilliant! I'm a Performing Arts teacher and I've been doing improv games with my students to help them step outside of their comfort zone. We have been doing mime, focussing on facial expressions and gestures. Then we levelled up to acting out a short scene with the added complexity of voice, but in a weird way (singing like an opera singer, speaking like an old man, or with a very slow deep voice etc). My biggest challenge has been getting them to jump in and do it with effort and conviction. Modelling has helped but I'm going to try the same intro your teacher did. I think that will get the last few students over the line. Thank you so very much. ❤

video_title: No. 1 Communication Expert: This Speaking Mistake Makes People Dislike You! Vinh Giang
comment_text:
This is very familiar topic for me as I have studied hypnosis as well as singing and healing through liberation of voice ranges (for myself and for others). I like his energy. I agree with a lot of what he is saying in terms of people having been blocked (by mostly adverse childhood experiences) in their vocal expressions and there are ways of unblocking it (can be quite fast actually). Exercises and examples given are good. Yet I still feel there's a bit of "acting" in his presence and way of communicating. Yes he is animated, smiles and I sense a hit of "studiedness" of it all, like there's a layer of these behaviours on top of the "real him". Hard to explain, it's very subtle to me. Technically what I noticed is what he has been missing in his way of speaking is aligning the tone of voice and speed and inflection to what he is communicating. He says "slow it all the way down" to Steven while raising pitch and speeding up himself. This feels incongruent. Around 31:30 . Also he didn't give Steven enough time to give his own answers and breathe during the "experiment" with the 3 melodies he played for them to listen to and find words to describe them. He gave his own almost as if overriding Steven, that felt a bit disrespectful, as if his teaching in that moment was more important than listening to Steven's answers. He gives plenty of good examples and shares a lot of knowledge from NLP.
01:10:00 Projection... Most often when people are on the podcast they project their own beliefs on Steven... And so they show this with their body too, not just verbally...

I really enjoyed the second part of the podcast when he shifted from "teaching" to speaking about his experiences and stories about his son, his father etc, that felt so much more authentic and open. I saw the difference in energy also between them two in the first and second part, Steven also looked much more relaxed in the latter, that should say something too. 
Conclusion - learn how to allow the techniques he teaches to help you to gain confidence to be truly authentic and vulnerable to share your experiences and stories and with true emotions and body impulses rather than supressing them and never let the techniques overtake the real emotional connections with people.
Despite those few bits that felt a little off to me, I enjoyed the time spent watching the episode and thank you for bringing that guest in.
